captions.text:
...and I ate this burrito and I think I got
food poisoning…
That sucks, how long was the incubation period?
*confused* what??

Hey everyone, Trace here for DNews! My buddy
Jared who runs the DNews social media pages

got food poisoning today, so we thought we'd
pull back the curtain on foodborne illness.

People CALL it food poisoning, but the medical
community call it foodborne illness, which

makes sense. You're not being poisoned by
food, but infected by something that's living

on the food. Commonly, food poisoning is caused
by bacteria, viruses, molds, toxins, parasites
or allergens.

They range from the fairly well known, E.
Coli and Salmonella to the far less known

campylobacter, toxoplasma, listeria and clostridium
perfringens (clostridEum per-fringe-ens).

According to the FDA, most foodborne illnesses
go away on their own and don't have lasting

effects -- but there are those, like E. Coli
O157:H7 which can cause kidney failure and

death if not treated properly. Not all e.coli
is bad, by the way. Some e.coli is part of
your natural gut bacteria!

A number of things can result in food being
"poisoned" or infected. Most often, according

to the Mayo Clinic, food poisoning comes from
food that’s mishandled or not cooked properly.

Maybe it's left under the warmer too long,
not refrigerated properly, handled by a person

who didn't wash their hands, or touched a
surface that wasn't recently cleaned. Every

contaminant has an ideal condition, and they
vary from bacteria to virus.

And though you might be thinking, YES! I was
at that place around the corner and TOTALLY

got it from there, you might be wrong. Some
of these foodborne illnesses can strike days

or weeks after exposure because it takes a
while for the organism to replicate in your

body and strike -- this is the incubation
period.

The most common pathogens, C. Perfringens,
Salmonella and the Norovirus have short incubation

periods ranging from 6-72 hours. All three
cause diarrhea, but while salmonella and norovirus

ALSO cause vomiting, c. perfringens doesn't!
E.coli and campylobacter incubate for several

days before striking and both result in severe
diarrhea containing blood, and vomiting. Toxoplasma

can incubate for weeks and produce no symptoms
at all, and listeria can live in your body

from three to SEVENTY DAYS before showing
flu-like symptoms! You could eat something

two weeks before Halloween and not feel it
til Christmas!

Some cases of food poisoning or food borne
illness are even mistaken for the flu, because

people can't remember when they ate at that
dodgy deli. And again, most of the time, you'll

just get better on your own, thanks to the
immune system. But you won't feel awesome.

These diseases cause diarrhea because they're
inhibiting your body from absorbing nutrients

and water OR they're causing MORE water to
be added into the bowel. This means your body

has to pass all that stuff out of your digestive
system, and in a hurry.

If you're nerds, like us,
you can look up your symptoms on foodsafety.gov

and know what you got, how long you've had
it, and what probably caused it! It's, like,

really nerdy. Also -- drink lots of water,
but NOT caffeine or dairy because your stomach

is already irritated, those will make it worse.
Make sure you consume some broth or electrolyte

drink to keep some nutrients flowing too.
And, speaking of flow, DON'T try and stop

the flow out yer butt with anti-diarrhea meds.
You're body's doing it on purpose, you'll

just get in the way, literally. If you see
blood, call a doctor. When was the last time
you got food poisoning? Where'd you get it?

Tell us down below in the comments and be
sure you subscribe for more DNews. And as

long as you're in the subscribing mood, check
out TestTube, a show that explains the facts

behind world news, politics and events that
affect us all!

Yesterday I was in a supermarket where you could have a taste of cheese, 
meat and - fish. I don't know but last night I couldn't sleep, my intestine 
rumbled and bubbled. In the morning I had awful headache, the during the 
forenoon I got extreme stomach cramps. Some hours ago I started to puke. 
It's awful. My stomach is so empty that there's nothing to puke anymore. 
And my head explodes. I don't think it's dangerous (I hope - at the moment 
it's bearable), but it's interesting: you cannot even taste things. It were 
really only all in all two tablespoons of fishsalad and fish pie.﻿
comments.author: MagicCoffeeBrain

comments.text:
Jakarta indonesia, not the cleanest place in the world but i,ve had no 
problems living here for almost 15 years on and off. had a cheese toasty 
yesterday morning for brunch. At 16.00 i went to a friends small bbq, i 
wasnt too hungery, i had fries, medium cooked steak and crusty bread with 
butter. I felt the steak didnt taste the best, its a long time since i had 
a bbq steak. two beers and coke from the can. I went home by 21.00 and felt 
fine but was woken at 2 am by severe stomache cramps thoughout my gut from 
stomache to lower bowel. I had very watery diarrhea and then the vomiting 
started until i was empty and totally drained over next 1.5 hours. I slept 
so bad with almost continual cramps. Woke up this morning awful, body 
aching, headache, abdominal cramps, dizzy, low blood pressure. I had no 
appetite so i took an imodium tablet on empty stomache. 30 mins later awful 
wretching until the disolved imodium came out bright yellow. I just spent 
all today monday in bed, sipping water and dry cream crackers. Texted my 
friend but he said other guests didnt report a problem, he was fine too, 
the beef was fresh from rancher supermarket. He said maybe rrom the coke 
can but i,m not convinced. Just random bad luck i suppose, maybe a dirty 
fly only landed on my steak. I cant see where else it came from.﻿

comments.text:
Interesting video. Thanks for sharing. I've been bedridden for a day now 
after eating some sandwich from a fast food chain restaurant. It was my 
co-worker's birthday, and she requested that restaurant. I've been puking 
off and on throughout the day. I have diarrhea, queasy stomach, my body 
feels warm and cold at the same time, I feel achy all over, I feel 
dehydrated and weak. I feel like I want to puke again. Anyways, it's no fun 
running to the toilet for various reasons each hour, every hour since 
Friday. My sister's cat was looking at me - like what the heck happened to 
you? The sight of food right now makes me sick. I've been drinking 
vitaminwater drinks, coconut water, eating a few oranges, and some orange 
Jell-O. Hopefully, I will get to feeling better tomorrow. I've had food 
poisoning before, but it wasn't THIS BAD. Plus, it doesn't help that I'm 
going through my period at the same time of this food poisoning. Everything 
happening all at once. Anyways, it's nice to watch some YouTube videos 
while I'm in bed. Thanks. ﻿

comments.text:
I can't remember when I last got food poisoning, whether that is because I 
mainly eat food cooked at home and me being careful with washing my hands 
before or because my immune system somehow manages to take care of the 
problem before i get the symptoms/without giving me symptoms, I have no 
idea.

One little note to certain people saying we should eating animal products: 
We humans has evolved to handle animal products for many reasons. We are 
omnivores, which means we eat both plants and animals, our teeth are 
adapted to both, though our canines are much less prominent than most other 
omnivores and carnivores. Another example is us being able to eat dairy 
products which a long time ago we would not have been able to eat, but 
thanks to evolution, a long long time ago, people in the north of europe 
and other parts of the world where the sun shines less made our skin 
lighter in colour and made it so we can eat dairy products (most of the 
time anyway) to make it easier for us when living in cloudy climates with 
less sun hours to get the optimal amount of vitamin D.
Also, meat from animals is a great source of proteins, some of the 
proteins/amino acids we get from animal meat is really difficult to come by 
through living a vegan life, of course its not impossible but there are 
essential amino acids, vitamins and minerals that we can not aquire from 
plants but only from animal products.﻿

comments.author: Myles Prower

comments.text:
+ghostofdayinperson While I do not dispute your evidence, I do have 
something to say about your interpretation. Can Humans subsist on a strict 
vegetarian diet? Yes. Does that mean our digestive systems cannot handle 
animal products, or that we should not eat animal products? No.

Our digestive system is of a configuration that allows us to consume both 
plant and animal products. Ours is in between that of a herbivore and a 
carnivore. We have molars that allow us to grind our food, incisors that 
help cut up plant matter, but also canines that allow us to tear meat, but 
none of these teeth are particularly pronounce over any other. Our saliva 
is alkaline, which means we are adapted to vegetables, but that does not 
exclude eating meat. The length of our GI tract allows us to digest plant 
material, but again, does not preclude meat. We do not have any other 
adaptations to process plants material before food reaches our stomach as 
herbivores do, and this aspect is consistent with carnivores. I can go on 
and on, but for your reference: 
http://learningon.theloop.school.nz/moodle/mod/page/view.php?id=48128. As 
you can see, human beings have some properties of both carnivores and 
herbivores, meaning we evolved to subsist naturally on a blend of meat and 
vegetables. It is down to personal choice, however, if you wish to become a 
pure vegetarian or a vegan, it is not a problem, as a varied enough 
vegetarian diet will see that you gain all the nutrition you need. If you 
choose to subsist on animal products alone, I would advise against it, 
since meat lack dietary fibre, which will do harm over the long run.﻿
comments.author: lcyw20

comments.text:
I've had food poisoning multiple times in my life the worst one was about 
three years ago. I was bed ridden for 3 days, vomiting and diarrhea the 
whole time (about every 45 minutes). Believe it or not, water (in this type 
of case) isn't the end all be all, gatoraid was easier to keep down. 

What sucks is after the vomiting/diarrhea stops, after three days, your 
muscles will feel incredibly sore. I literally (not figuratively) could not 
walk for 6 hours because my muscles (mainly abs) felt like I had worked out 
for two days. Even my arms, and feet hurt. Doc said it was a by product of 
my body purging itself of the toxins.

Another thing to watch out for is after the food borne illness is over. Do 
not immediately resume your normal eating habits. This can (at least in my 
case) cause your stomach to fail to empty, which meant a stomach pump in my 
circumstance. Instead, start off with "clear foods" (broth, apple juice, 
jello etc) gradually introducing solid foods over a two or three day 
period. You'll thank yourself later. 

And yes, that month really sucked.﻿
comments.author: The Seph I am

comments.text:
I have had some bad diarrhoea from my food once, but that was only because 
I ate way too many waffles, and it was over after one day (although it 
wasn't fun having what's essentially brown pee coming out of your butt). I 
have a pretty strong system. Ate a lot of weird things without problem, had 
3 slight coughs when I got a disease that nearly made my brother cough his 
lungs out... It's probably my goa'uld ﻿
comments.author: Marco Onyxheart
